title: How is this game any representation of ones own skill?
body:
When the worst person out of 10 players decides your fate. Sometimes two.

"Team Game"
aka
Pray you get lucky.

replies.body:
The best way I can describe the "skill" and attitude in league is double dutch jump rope. A team where the people holding the rope (let's call them rhythm keepers) keep a rhythm and the jumper keeping his own rhythm. But how is the jumper suppose to do anything if the others can't keep there rhythm? then you have high ello players, or in this example, good "rhythm keepers" come in here telling the jumper on the other team "it's not your team members you just need to learn and git gud"
In league of course you are a rhythm keeper and a jumper, work with your team as well as managing your own skill. But ya this is how I see league and the condescending attitudes of the "glorious" high ello players

it doesn't. also maintaining a placement division like silver/gold or higher is A LOT easier than getting out of one.. higher ello players will swear up and down that ello hell doesn't exists, this let's them pet their ego so they can feel better than lower ello players. In bronze and silver I'd say your chances of winning are 90% what team you got (I.E feeders, afk'ers), what champions and 10% personal skill.

In bronze and silver I'd say your chances of winning are 90% what team you got (I.E feeders, afk'ers), what champions and 10% personal skill.

Honestly if people are still stuck in bronze/silver after a 100-150 games then they aren't improving they are just playing.  To actively improve requires not only the drive to improve but the ability to recognize ones mistakes and activley try and fix them the next game.  

Things like remembering enemy summoner times, roughly judging where the enemy jungle is, wave control, zone control, rotations, champion matchups, good ward placements and locations, good cs etc.  All these things need to be researched out of the game through guides, videos and having someone explain it and then thought about in game.  Not everything at once, but one at a time until they are all mastered.

If after a game people are just thinking "yeah yeah, I lost, I probably need to ward some more in lane so I die less to ganks" but don't do it next game they can play 1000 games and still be stuck in bronze/silver

There's a reason some people consistently climb into silver/gold/plat/diamond/master/challenger and some don't, and it isn't because of champion balance or coin flips.
